topics.body:
Wow I'm pissed off!

I today realized why there's so many security holes and bugs in a lot of websites, programs and operating systems: a metric fuck ton of programmers suck at intermediate and higher levels of math.

I just had a hour long argument with my teacher and the whole thing can be summarized as:
"The book's equation is wrong"
"Nuh-uh the book can't be wrong it's you that's wrong"
"Here's the math on it to prove the book is wrong"
"Then math itself is wrong"
"Math is a absolute science; if math says you're wrong then you're wrong"
"Nuh-uh programing is more pure of a science; if math is wrong then change how math works to make it fit the program"
"If you used this program in real life it would cause a twenty car pile up and kill dozens"
"Nuh-uh you're wrong cause everyone else got the program to output the right output so you're wrong"
"And that's a straw man fallacy"
"No one else had this problem except you"
"Doesn't mean they're right"
"Did anyone else have this problem?"
*someone sticks his hand up
"Can you help him?"
"Okay"

"So you had the same problem?"
"Yeah; the teacher's a idiot; just use this and call it done"
"Didn't you try to explain this to him?"
"Yeah and he told me the same thing; just use this and walk away"
"But that's screwed up; he's telling us that any time a math equation is incorrect that you're wrong instead"
"I know, but he's not going to back down"



No wonder why there's so many holes in software cause if the vast majority of people taking programming can't understand that if a equation is wrong then it's going to give the wrong output then that's going to cause a fuck ton of problems.

Intermediate and higher levels of math should be a requirement for anyone taking programming cause if you are under the assumption that you can NOT be wrong under any situation and therefore any math to prove you wrong is itself wrong then that's going to cause a fuck ton of problems.

Tl:dr; My teacher's a idiot and I need a drink badly cause damn that's some hard core stupidity there.


Here's a wild suggestion: If your output is wrong then maybe you should go and on pen and paper go through your math to see where it's wrong rather then automatically assume that math itself as a science is wrong first cause I sure don't see aeronautical engineers or such every time a airplane descends too quickly throwing out all of physics and going, "nope gravity is wrong".
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.author: 4fe16df67f123b13e400003f

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53add67e6368722bbf680200#post_53add67e6368722bbf680200
[bq="Whatevs"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53adcfb46368722426430100#post_53adcfb46368722426430100
hahahaha. Your anguish sustains me[/bq]
My anguish summarized in a nutshell:
"If this program was put into action in the real world it would kill someone. . . literally"


Now that I think about it a lot of problems in the real world programming industry could be prevented if people just once in a while fucking double checked their work.


"Hey maybe we should take five minutes to make sure this is correct before we implement the change?"
"Nah"
*five seconds later someone steals five million dollars from the company cause the program was incorrect and thus let people access the company's finances


Imagine if heart surgeons had this mentality:
"Don't we need to attach the arteries and such to the heart?"
"Eh; sticking it in the chest cavity is close enough"
"Yeah; you're right; let's close him up."
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
